docs.lead_paragraph: A federal judge upheld part of a South Dakota law that requires women to be told abortion ends a human life.

headline.main: Both Sides Claim Victory in Ruling Over Abortion Law
headline.print_headline: Both Sides Claim Victory in Ruling Over South Dakota’s Abortion Law

docs.snippet: A federal judge upheld part of a South Dakota law that requires women to be told abortion ends a human life.

docs.lead_paragraph: I don't know when I'll recover from "Octomom: The Incredible Unseen Footage,'' the two-hour documentary that aired on Fox on Wednesday night and failed to produce a second's worth of contrarian evidence that Nadya Suleman isn't a self-obsessed, publicity-driven lunatic. Of course, I don't know if I ever recovered from first seeing the image, shown here again, of Ms. Suleman's Hyundai-sized belly during her final months of pregnancy, ridden with enough stretch marks to look like a Nascar track.
docs.abstract: "Octomom: The Incredible Unseen Footage,'' a two-hour documentary that aired on Fox on Wednesday night, failed to produce a second's worth of contrarian evidence that Nadya Suleman isn't a self-obsessed, publicity-driven lunatic.

docs.lead_paragraph: This post contains spoilers. If you don't want to know what happened in 1963 (or so), read no further.
docs.abstract: If the third season of "Mad Men" didn't quite begin with the jumpstart we were hoping for, it did pick up nicely where Season 2 left off. Like a comfortable Thanksgiving dinner, every crazy member of this extended family was reliably acting out his or her established role.

docs.lead_paragraph: As much fun as it is to revel in fascination at the early 1960s seen in “Mad Men,” the series works best as a startling reminder of just how distant the near past really is.
